Award.AwardTitle: Support for Analog Modeling of Tectonic Processes Workshop
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project provides funding for travel support for U.S. researchers and students to attend a workshop on "Analog Modeling of Tectonic Processes" to be held in Amherst, Massachusetts, in early May of 2015. Analog model experiments contribute substantially to the understanding of tectonic processes. In these experiments, weaker materials (sand, clay, etc.) take the place rocks and are deformed at high strain rates under controlled conditions thus producing scale models of the development of earth structures (faults, folds) and large-scale tectonic features (mountain belts, rift systems). The aim of this workshop is to bring together the structural geology analog modeling community to discuss exciting innovations in analog modeling research, authentic science curriculum materials, and future directions for analog modeling. This community includes analog experimentalists, students, instructors who use analog models in their classrooms and researchers who are interested in comparing their observations to analog experiment results. The workshop will promote the analog modeling skills of early career structural geologists, thereby developing the future workforce in tectonics. The conference will promote the participation of students, early career scientists, and researchers from underrepresented groups in the earth sciences.

The past 10 years have seen a revolution within analog modeling of crustal deformation spurred by systematic rheological testing of analog materials and use of laser and image processing techniques for data analysis leading to a strengthening of the quantitative aspect of analog modeling. The vanguard of this revolution has been in Europe where laboratories have been implementing new approaches that permit greater control on experimental conditions, more accurate scaling of deformation and improved insights into the evolution of deformation and deformation processes. This multi-day workshop on analog modeling combines discussions on experimental approaches with presentation of scientific findings. The workshop involves: (1) running an experiment at the host lab; (2) discussions of various approaches, techniques and data analysis tools; (3) discussion on needs of the community and future directions for analog modeling research; and (4) exercises devoted to bringing analog experiments into the classroom.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Tectonic deformation in our Earth’s crust can produce devastating landslides, earthquakes and volcanic eruptions. The job of geoscientists to understand this deformation is challenged by our limited ability to see and measure conditions within the crust. Physical experiments that model tectonic processes provide a way to directly observe deformation similar to what happens in the Earth’s crust.  Consequently, these experiments hold the key to connecting the deformed outcrops geologists investigate in the nature with deformation produced by mathematical and computer models. New techniques of digital image correlation and measurement of material properties are ushering in a quantitative revolution for physical experiments that has not yet taken hold in many labs. In order to facilitate communication and sharing of new approaches among geoscientists researching and teaching about crustal deformation within the United States, we hosted a NSF sponsored workshop on Analog Modeling of Tectonic Processes May 13-15, 2015 at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.  This workshop was followed by publication of a paper on the value of physical experiments and funded visits of students to various labs to enrich their experimental expertise.

 

Workshop

The workshop provided a forum for a wide range of geoscientists studying tectonic processes. Experienced researchers compared and discussed their approaches thereby learning from each other. The methods focus of this workshop allowed researchers from different disciplines who usually attend different disciplinary conferences to learn from one another. Graduate students and early career scientists gained exposure to tools that helped their research and networking that helped their career development.  The international workshop drew researchers and instructors using physical models to promote an active exchange both between and among the two groups. The 46 workshop participants included 20 students (undergraduate through PhD) and three post docs. Eight of the 46 participants are European and 4 of these traveled to the conference on their own funds.

 

The workshop succeeded not only in connecting physical modelers across research topics but also focused on sharing the innovative use physical models by geoscience instructors in their curriculum thereby strengthening the connection between experimental research and instructional activities. Of the 23 professionals, 5 are teaching focused and came to the workshop to learn and share instructional activities.  The remaining 18 professionals were interested in using experiments for research and many of these professionals also use experiments within their classrooms.  Besides seven invited talks and poster presentations from most participants, several demonstrations of experiments showcased new techniques, approaches, and classroom activities.

 

Paper

The PI, Michele Cooke (UMass Amherst) along with Jacqueline Reber (Univesity of Iowa) and Saad Haw (Purdue Univesrity) developed a paper promoting the integration of physical experiments within research endeavors in GSA Today. Our intent was to reach a wide audience of geoscientists and work towards dispelling notions that scaled physical experiments are not rigorous enough for research.

 

Student Lab Visits

13 undergraduate and graduate students participated in our program for students to visit physical experimental labs in order to learn more about different experimental procedures. PIs and students all reported tremendous benefits from the program.  The students were from Macalester College, Suny Geneseo, UT San Antonio, Iowa State and University of Rhode Island. They visited labs of Jacqueline Reber at Iowa State, Danielle Wyrick at Southwest Research Institute, Michele Cooke at UMass-Amherst and Karen Daniels at North Carolina State.
